Larry Fedora: s statement: The first aspect employed to verify the authenticity of the claim is the direct statement made by Larry Fedora, the head coach of the UNC football team. He explicitly stated, "I don’t think it’s been proven that the game of football causes CTE." This statement serves as the basis of the claim being evaluated.
Link between head trauma and CTE: The second aspect involves the scientific understanding of the link between head trauma and chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). Fedora acknowledged that repeated blows to the head can cause CTE, which aligns with the current scientific consensus on the subject.
Research on football and CTE: The third aspect includes the research conducted on the relationship between football and CTE. While it is challenging to definitively prove causation due to the inability to diagnose CTE in living individuals, studies have been conducted on deceased football players' brains. The 2017 study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that a significant percentage of examined brains tested positive for CTE, suggesting a link between football and the disease.
Expert opinion: The fourth aspect involves the expert opinion of Dr. Ann McKee, one of the researchers involved in the 2017 study. She affirmed that the results of the study indicate a problem with CTE in football, stating, "We’re seeing this (CTE) in a very large number that participated in football for many years. So while we don’t know the exact risk and we don’t know the exact number, we know this is a problem in football." This expert opinion further supports the claim that football is linked to CTE.
